title: UI Buttons Settings
content:
## Customizing Control Buttons

You can choose which control buttons appear in the main window. This keeps your interface clean and focused on the features you actually use.

## Accessing UI Buttons Settings

1. Click **Settings** gear icon ⚙️ (or press `Ctrl+,`)
2. Select the **UI Buttons** tab
3. Check/uncheck buttons you want visible
4. Click **Apply** to update the main window

## Available Control Buttons

**Always Recommended:**
- ☑ **Power On/Off** - Essential for basic control
- ☑ **Input Source** - Switch between HDMI/VGA/etc.

**Presentation Features:**
- ☑ **Blank Screen** - Hide projected image temporarily
- ☑ **Freeze Display** - Pause projected image

**Advanced Features:**
- ☐ **Volume Control** - Adjust projector volume (if supported)
- ☐ **Mute Audio** - Quick mute toggle
- ☐ **Picture Mode** - Switch between Presentation/Cinema/etc.
- ☐ **Aspect Ratio** - Change 16:9, 4:3, etc.
- ☐ **Info/Status** - Quick status display

## Common Button Configurations

**Basic User (Minimal Interface):**
- Power On/Off
- Input Source

**Presenter (Most Common):**
- Power On/Off
- Input Source
- Blank Screen
- Freeze Display

**Advanced User (All Features):**
- All buttons enabled

## Preview Before Applying

The preview section shows a miniature version of your main window with your selected buttons. Use this to see the layout before applying changes.

## What Happens When You Hide Buttons?

**Hidden buttons are not disabled:**
- Features still work
- Accessible from system tray menu
- Available via keyboard shortcuts
- Just not visible in main window

**Benefits of hiding unused buttons:**
- Cleaner, simpler interface
- Easier to find buttons you need
- Less overwhelming for basic users
- Smaller main window size

## Compatibility Note

Some buttons only appear if your projector supports the feature:
- Volume Control - Requires audio-capable projector
- Picture Mode - Requires mode switching support
- Some features only on PJLink Class 2 projectors

If a button is grayed out even when enabled, your projector does not support that feature.

> **Tip:** Keep your interface clean by hiding buttons you rarely use. You can always enable them later if needed.
